description: From Middle English parent, borrowed from Anglo-Norman parent, Middle French parent, from Latin parentem, accusative of parēns (“parent”), present participle of parere (“to breed, bring forth”).

entries.meaning: One of the two persons from whom one is immediately biologically descended; a mother or father. [from 15th c.]
examples: After both her parents were killed in a forest fire, Sonia was adopted by her aunt and uncle.

entries.meaning: A third person who has provided DNA samples in an IVF procedure in order to alter faulty genetic material
A person who acts as a parent in rearing a child; a step-parent or adoptive parent.
The source or origin of something. [from 16th c.]
examples: Misery is often the parent of the most affecting touches in poetry.

entries.meaning: (biology) An organism from which a plant or animal is immediately biologically descended. [from 17th c.]
(computing) The object from which a child or derived object is descended; a node superior to another node. [from 20th c.]
(physics) The nuclide that decays into a daughter nuclide.

verbs.description: parent (third-person singular simple present parents, present participle parenting, simple past and past participle parented)

entries.meaning: To act as parent, to raise or rear.
